AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya: defendant whose punishment is being determined based on the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual, with a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel and a denied motion for relief
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Nancy F. Atlas: judge who concludes that jurists of reason would not debate whether the movant has stated a valid claim or whether any procedural ruling in this case was correct, and orders the denial of Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's motion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America: plaintiff in the case, whose motions to dismiss and expand the record were granted by Nancy F. Atlas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens, held against their will for ransom demand
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.foreign nationals: persons held for ransom and against their will, involved in an illegal alien smuggling venture
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.six co-defendants: co-defendants of Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya found guilty as charged on all counts of the superseding indictment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.five-count superseding indictment: indictment against Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya and co-defendants, including charges related to hostage-taking offenses
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Federal Grand Jury: grand jury that found Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya and co-defendants guilty as charged on all counts of the superseding indictment and returned a supplemental verdict
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.supplemental verdict: verdict returned by the United States Federal Grand Jury, finding that the hostage-taking offense involved between six and twenty-four aliens and a firearm was brandished or otherwise used and possessed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Presentence Report: report prepared for determining punishment under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual, including calculations of total offense level based on the most serious count among the group
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.PSR: abbreviation for Presentence Report, used in determining sentence based on the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Guidelines Manu: manual used to determine sentences, with specific guidelines for ex post facto laws and amendments affecting base offense levels, applied in Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's case to calculate a total offense level of 40
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the hostage-taking offense: offense involving the holding of aliens against their will for ransom demand, with a firearm brandished or otherwise used and possessed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the ransom demand: demand made during the commission of the hostage-taking offense, involving the possession of a dangerous weapon
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the dangerous weapon: weapon used in connection with the hostage-taking offense, found to be possessed by Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the firearm: firearm brandished or otherwise used and possessed during the hostage-taking offense
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens
